docs.text: warning : this review contains some spoilers for the 1964 film " fail-safe . "
docs.label: positive

docs.text: if you haven't seen the film yet , proceed with caution .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: nutshell : a relevant , intelligent , suspenseful drama .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: still powerful today , even after the end of the cold war .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: -------------------- " fail-safe " ( usa , 1964 ) drama , 111 minutes
docs.label: positive

docs.text: screenplay by walter bernstein based on the novel by eugene burdick and harvey wheeler produced by max e . youngstein directed by sidney lumet
docs.label: positive

docs.text: review by jamahl epsicokhan --------------------
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the most ironic aspect of nuclear war is that it doesn't have a winning side and a losing side .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: in a nuclear confrontation , everybody loses , and the aftereffects have devastating effects that impact the entire world--assuming the world survives .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the idea--and perhaps the only real option--is to avoid war at all costs .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: this is the theme of sidney lumet's " fail-safe , " a fictional drama based on the novel by eugene burdick and harvey wheeler .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: " fail-safe " takes place during the heart of the cold war ( the actual film was released two years after the cuban missile crisis ) , when the united states and the soviet union were in static discord over an issue that can be summarized in a single word : communism .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the premise centers around a combination of accidents and operation flaws .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: five u . s . bombers carrying nuclear warheads are ordered to set a routine course for moscow after an unidentified aircraft is spotted heading toward america .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the unidentified aircraft turns out to be a commercial airliner , but a mechanical failure strikes the military base that commands the bombers .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: suddenly out of contact , and with standing orders to remain on course until receiving new directives , the bomber pilots cannot be recalled , and they proceed to moscow with the intention of destroying it with a nuclear strike .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: a great deal of " fail-safe " 's plot follows various characters as they attempt to devise ways of stopping the u . s . bombers from reaching russia's borders--at any cost .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the plot is compelling , and the story creates urgency and dread by painting the grimmest of worst case scenarios .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the reality sets in quickly as one attempt to turn the bombers after another fails .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: general bogan ( frank overton ) , taking orders directly from the president of the united states himself ( henry fonda ) , is powerless--the fate of the world lies in the hands of an automated , pre-programmed system that may not be stoppable , simply because the creators of the war machines were too efficient in their task to make a no-win situation winnable .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the events in " fail-safe " are fascinating because they're anything but predictable , but the real reason " fail-safe " works is because it understands more about nuclear war than what exists within the confines of its plot .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: a key ingredient to the film is its ability to create an ongoing polemic about nuclear war , communism , the cold war , and the united states' role in all of it .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: most of this is through the film's use of the character groeteschele ( walter matthau ) , an arrogant civilian theorist of nuclear weapons use who , incidentally , is on the president's advising staff for analyzing the statistical plausibility of waging a nuclear war .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: many of the film's most pointed messages arise from discussions where groeteschele is one of the key voices .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: early in the film , he hosts a dinner party where he explains the importance of " strategy " in a nuclear assault to " minimize " casualties .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: " what's the difference between 60 million and 100 million dead ? "
docs.label: positive

docs.text: a guest asks impatiently .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: " forty million , " groeteschele responds wryly .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the problem with groeteschele's mindset is that he * believes * nuclear combat to be a viable method of war .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the only difference to him between nuclear armageddon and conventional warfare is the raw data and the casualty totals .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: groeteschele realizes that these weapons can destroy the world several times over .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: yet his answer to the arms race is not to slow down and try to cool the situation off , as general black ( dan o'herlihy ) has often recommended .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: on the contrary--according to groeteschele , that would lead to russia having * more * nuclear weapons than the u . s . , which would clearly put america at a disadvantage .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: such a stance was perhaps the central paradox and misguided practice of the arms race .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: " fail-safe " clearly sees it as one of the central issues of the cold war , and , likewise , it becomes a central theme in the film .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: why continue to build such machines of mass destruction while already possessing enough of them to destroy the world several times over ?
docs.label: positive

docs.text: is it wise ?
docs.label: positive

docs.text: is it even logical ?
docs.label: positive

docs.text: no , not really .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: although " fail-safe " is more about the issue of nuclear weapons than it is about the political ramifications of communism , there is a scene in the film that deals with communism in an intentionally superficial , one-sided sort of way .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: again , this is achieved through groeteschele , who is easily the film's most important character in terms of the larger-theme significance .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: in addition to providing the central " pro-nuclear war " voice that the film warns against , he also makes key remarks about communists that show just how much fear and resentment people of the period were prone to when it came to communism .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the context the film uses suggests that this hatred was often glib .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: one of groeteschele's " logical " trains of thought ventures so far into fantasy theoretical prediction that it's merely absurd .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he labels the average marxist an " unfeeling , calculating machine " that will do whatever it takes to preserve itself .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: groeteschele takes it so far as to say that if the u . s . drops the warhead on moscow , the soviets will * instantly * surrender , for to retaliate would invite counter-measures that would further destroy russia's home soil--which must be preserved at all costs .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: groeteschele seems to forget these people are human beings with emotions ; general black quickly reminds him that the soviets would attack out of revenge--as any normal person would .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the irony here is groeteschele's own mechanical theorizing .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: he is so quick to judge the enemy that he doesn't even realize his own seemingly programmed thought patterns .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: once the film makes it evident that turning the u . s . bombers will be impossible , the question becomes what the * consequences * of destroying moscow will be .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: just how will the soviet union's leader react , and what can the president do to convey his best intentions ?
docs.label: positive

docs.text: ( just * how * does one pass off the deaths of millions of people as an * mishap * ? )
docs.label: positive

docs.text: with the help of his translator buck ( larry hagman ) , the president negotiates at length with the soviet leader , in scenes that prove amazingly taut and powerful in their simplicity , with lumet's long takes of fonda and hagman in the same frame , exchanging the dialog between the president and the soviet leader .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: without getting into too much detail , i will say that the compromise they ultimately reach is very costly , yet necessary and as sensible as possible under the circumstances .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: ( that is , as sensible as a nuclear " incident " can probably be . )
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it does accomplish what it must : it avoids an all-out war , something that simply isn't possible because of its all-too-real consequences .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: dramatically , the ending is quite powerful , and the use of o'herlihy's character as the symbolic " matador " ( providing a bookend to the film by ending the story while tying into his dream sequence from the film's opening ) , is particularly appropriate .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: " fail-safe " is a production of a major hollywood studio ( released by columbia pictures ) , and it has the structure of a high-tension suspense thriller that one might expect from a hollywood film .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: nevertheless , under lumet's direction and walter bernstein's intelligent adaptation of burdick's and wheeler's novel , the film continues to have a lasting effect even after the events on screen have unfolded .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the film often warns that the automation of war is something that may make nuclear holocaust an unintentional consequence of such mass arming .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: but it was the conscious , human choice to * initialize * this automatic arming that " fail-safe " also finds dangerous .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: in retrospect , the arms race seems to be one of the most puzzling exercises in futility of the century .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it's just fortunate that both sides were finally able to come to their senses and slow down , rather than continuing groeteschele's dangerous approach of speeding up and causing a possible meltdown .
docs.label: positive
